title: 104_hr125
content: The Act may be cited as the "Gun Crime Enforcement and Second Amendment Restoration Act of 1996". The Congress finds that protecting citizens from armed violent criminals is crucial for public safety. Banning specific firearms does not deter criminals, so the focus should be on arresting, convicting, and incarcerating them to prevent reoffending. The Attorney General must establish an armed violent criminal apprehension program within 180 days of this Act. Each US attorney must appoint a prosecutor and create a task force to remove armed violent criminals from the streets. The program should focus on severe punishment to deter armed violent crime and consider Federal and State laws for apprehension and prosecution. The Attorney General must establish an armed violent criminal apprehension program within 180 days of this Act, focusing on deterring armed violent crime and considering the effectiveness of Federal and State laws. Each US attorney must appoint a prosecutor and create a task force to address the nature and extent of violent crime in their district, while also considering limited Federal involvement in traditionally State and local prosecuted crimes. The Attorney General shall require monthly reports on the number of defendants charged with armed violent crimes. The Attorney General shall require US attorneys to report the number of defendants charged with violating specific sections of the United States Code. The Attorney General must submit a compilation of this information to Congress twice a year, along with a report on waivers granted. US attorneys can request waivers from the Attorney General for reporting requirements. The Attorney General may waive reporting requirements for US attorneys based on specific criteria such as the number of assistant attorneys and level of violent crime in the district. An "armed violent criminal" is defined as someone accused of certain firearm violations with a prior violent crime conviction. This section will expire at a certain date. The section defines an "armed violent criminal" as someone with a prior violent crime conviction or accused of specific firearm violations. It will expire after a 5-year period following the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4 of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 repeals prohibitions on semiautomatic assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices by amending various sections of title 18, United States Code. This includes striking subsections (v) and (w) of Section 922, paragraph (30) of Section 921(a), and making amendments to Section 921(a)(31)(A), Section 923(i), and Section 924(a)(1)(B). Additionally, Section 110104 of the Act is repealed. SEC. 5 mandates prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm or destructive device during a federal crime that is a crime of violence or a drug trafficking crime. Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include mandatory prison terms for possessing or brandishing a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking crime. Possession results in a 5-year sentence, while brandishing leads to a 10-year sentence. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code, mandates prison terms for possessing or brandishing a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. Brandishing a firearm results in a 10-year sentence, while discharging it with intent to injure leads to a 20-year sentence. Additional penalties apply for certain types of firearms. The possession of a firearm with a silencer or muffler can result in a 30-year imprisonment sentence. For second or subsequent convictions, additional penalties apply based on the circumstances, such as possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. The possession of a firearm with a silencer or muffler can result in a 30-year imprisonment sentence. For second or subsequent convictions, additional penalties apply based on the circumstances, such as discharging a firearm with intent to injure during a crime of violence or drug trafficking, leading to a minimum 30-year imprisonment or life imprisonment if certain types of firearms are involved. Probationary sentences are not allowed for violations of this law. The subsection imposes a term of imprisonment for firearm-related crimes, which does not run concurrently with other sentences. Those sentenced under this subsection cannot be released for any reason during their imprisonment. The House of Representatives passed the bill on March 22, 1996. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
